Package sprouts.impl

Class AbstractVariable<T>

java.lang.Object
sprouts.impl.AbstractVariable<T>
Type Parameters:
T - The type of the value wrapped by a given property...
All Implemented Interfaces:
Observable, Val<T>, Var<T>
public class AbstractVariable<T> extends Object implements Var<T>
The base implementation for both Var and Val interfaces. This also serves as a reference implementation for the concept of the Var/Val properties in general.

    • of

      public static <T> Var<T> of(Val<T> first, Val<T> second, BiFunction<T,T,T> combiner)
      Description copied from interface: Val
      Creates a read only Val property that constitutes a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function, which takes in the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them.
      The combiner function is invoked to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)) on either one...

      Note the property view does not permit storing null references! So if the combiner function returns a null reference on the first call, a NullPointerException will be thrown. If a null reference is returned on subsequent calls, the view will log a warning and simply retain the last non-null value!
      If you need a composite view which allows null, use the Val.ofNullable(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the items held by the properties.
      Parameters:
      first - The first property to be combined with the second property.
      second - The second property to be combined with the first property.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance which is a live view of the two given properties.

    • ofNullable

      public static <T> Var<T> ofNullable(Val<T> first, Val<T> second, BiFunction<T,T,T> combiner)
      Description copied from interface: Val
      Creates a read only Val property that constitutes a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function, which takes in the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them.
      The combiner function is invoked to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items of the two properties change, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)).

      Note that this property does permit storing null references.
      If you need a composite view which does not permit null, use the Val.of(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the items held by the properties.
      Parameters:
      first - The first property to be combined with the second property.
      second - The second property to be combined with the first property.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance which is a live view of the two given properties.

    • withId

    • onChange

      public Var<T> onChange(Channel channel, Action<Val<T>> action)
      Use this to register an observer lambda for a particular Channel, which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(Channel, T) method. The lambda will receive the current item of this property. The default channel is From.VIEW_MODEL, so if you use the Var::set(T) method then the observer lambdas registered through this method will be called.
      Specified by:
      onChange in interface Val<T>
      Specified by:
      onChange in interface Var<T>
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      action - The lambda which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Var changes.
      Returns:
      The Val instance itself.

    • fireChange

      public Var<T> fireChange(Channel channel)
      Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel. Change listeners may be registered using the Val.onChange(Channel, Action) method. Note that when the Var::set(T) method is called then this will automatically translate to fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL). So it is supposed to be used by the view to update the UI components. This is in essence how binding works in Swing-Tree.
      Specified by:
      fireChange in interface Val<T>
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      Returns:
      The Val instance itself.

    • set

      public Var<T> set(Channel channel, @Nullable T newItem)
      This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from a custom channel of your choice, usually one of the channels defined in From. It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
      Specified by:
      set in interface Var<T>
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
      Returns:
      This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.

    • viewAs

      public final <U> Val<U> viewAs(Class<U> type, Function<T,U> mapper)
      Use this to create a live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function.
      So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function.

      Note that this method will try to map value based item types like String, Integer, Double, etc. to the default value of their respective primitive types, if the provided mapping function returns a null reference.
      So for example, if this is a wrapper for a property of type Integer, and the mapping function returns a null reference, then the resulting view property will always contain the value 0 and its Val.allowsNull() method will always return false.

      The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately confusing user experiences.

      Also note that a property view may only contain null if the property it is based on was created with the "ofNullable(...)" factory method (in which case its Val.allowsNull() method will return true). Otherwise, it will throw an exception when trying to map a null reference.

      Specified by:
      viewAs in interface Val<T>
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • id

      public final String id()
      Returns the name/id of the property which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
      For example, when converting a property based model to a JSON object, the id of the properties can be used as keys in the JSON object.
      Specified by:

    • _triggerActions

      protected void _triggerActions(List<Action<Val<T>>> actions)

    • allowsNull

      public final boolean allowsNull()
      A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method. Otherwise, it will throw an IllegalArgumentException when trying to set a null reference. This flag cannot be changed after the property has been constructed!
      The purpose of this method is to warn the UI that this property can contain null items, so that it may throw an exception or do something else to handle this case. For many types of properties null is simply nonsensical, like String for example, where the absence of a value is represented by an empty string.
      Specified by:
      allowsNull in interface Val<T>
      Returns:
      true, if this property can contain null, false otherwise.
